Harvesting alkyl phenols from lignin monomers via selective hydrodeoxygenation under ambient pressure on Pd/α-MoC catalysts Haoquan Guo Investigation Formal analysis Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing a b Xinyu Lu Investigation Formal analysis a Yue Yang Investigation Formal analysis b Jinhe Wei Investigation Formal analysis b Lizhi Wu Formal analysis b Li Tan Formal analysis b Yu Tang Conceptualization Supervision Funding acquisition Writing – review & editing b ⁎ Xiaoli Gu Supervision Funding acquisition a ⁎ a Co-Innovation Center for Efficient Processing and Utilization of Forest Products, College of Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing 210037, China Co-Innovation Center for Efficient Processing and Utilization of Forest Products College of Chemical Engineering Nanjing Forestry University Nanjing 210037 China aCo-Innovation Center for Efficient Processing and Utilization of Forest Products, College of Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing 210037, China b Institute of Molecule Catalysis and In-Situ/Operando Studies, College of Chemistry, Fuzhou University, Fuzhou 350108, China Institute of Molecule Catalysis and In-Situ/Operando Studies College of Chemistry Fuzhou University Fuzhou 350108 China bInstitute of Molecule Catalysis and In-Situ/Operando Studies, College of Chemistry, Fuzhou University, Fuzhou 350108, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Alkyl phenol is an essential chemical intermediate that is in high demand in the chemical industry. The synthesis of alkyl phenols from lignin-derived molecules is one of the most promising routes for utilizing biomass resources. Herein, we report the catalytic hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of dihydroeugenol (DHE) to alkyl phenols over a highly dispersed Pd/α-MoC catalyst with a substrate conversion of 98% and a selectivity of 96% to alkyl phenols. The Pd/α-MoC catalyst prepared by co-precipitation and temperature-programmed carbonization exhibits exceptional HDO activity under mild conditions with a low H2 pressure (1–10 bars). The characterizations of the catalyst suggest that Pd are highly dispersed on the α-MoC matrix. The reaction mechanism was investigated using the substrate scope experiments. Under ambient pressure, the abundant oxygen vacancies and acidity sites on Pd/α-MoC enable the selective hydrodeoxygenation of lignin monomers. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biomass Hydrodeoxygenation Lignin Phenols Carbide Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Lignin, a complex polymer comprised of polyaromatic units, presents a compelling alternative to fossil-based resources as a source of essential compounds including alkyl phenols, olefins, and aromatic hydrocarbons [1,2]. Lignin is one of the most abundant and readily accessible forms of biomass, which can be obtained from lignocellulose materials and industrial waste [3–5]. Despite its potential, the complex structure of lignin, characterized by a plethora of CO (e.g., α-O-4, β-O-4, and 4-O-5) and CC (e.g., β-1, β-β, and 5-5) bonds, presents a challenge for the efficient conversion of lignin into high-value chemicals [6,7]. The conversion of lignin into monomer aromatic chemicals is a promising process, with the potential to produce high yields under moderate conditions. Currently, various thermochemical conversion pathways, such as hydrogenation, pyrolysis, and oxidation, are being explored. Of these, hydrogenation is a particularly promising method, with the potential to upgrade lignin into fuel-like chemicals. In earlier research, we examined the catalytic hydrogenolysis of alkali lignin utilizing Ni-W/ZrP catalysts and metal-supported alumina catalysts [8–10]. The Ni-W/ZrP catalysts and metal-supported alumina catalysts exhibited a high yield of bio-oil and superior catalytic selectivity for certain phenolic products, particularly for G-type phenols. However, the monomers converted from lignin usually contain one or more CO and Ar-OH bonds, such as G-type phenols and S-type phenols [11] The high binding energy of the CO bond hinders its dissociation. As a result, lignin and its derivatives have a low utilization value as raw materials in fine chemicals and bulk chemicals due to their high oxygen concentration [12]. Cleaving the CO bond without breaking other structures is therefore a critical challenge in lignin conversion. Selective cleavage of CO bonds by hydrodeoxygenation of lignin monomers to obtain alkyl phenols is a promising route for biomass upgrading [13,14]. Alkyl phenols are one kind of the most important chemical intermediates, which are widely used as surfactants, lubricant additives, antioxidants for rubber and plastics, and raw materials for the synthesis of phenolic resin [15,16]. The alkyl phenols are produced by thermal catalytic conversion of biomass and alkylation of phenols and olefins conventionally, [16–18] which requires huge cost of petroleum resources and energy. To date, numerous studies suggest lignin aromatic monomer is an alternative material with great potential to produce alkyl phenols [19–23]. Ji et al. presented a process to alkyl phenols from lignin over MoS2/AC [19]. The influence of the supports with different porosity and acidity was explored on the hydrogenation of eugenol. The acid-rich MoS2/AC with high specific surface areas and more exposed MoS2 edge sites owed a superior activity and selectivity in alkyl phenols production from not only model compound eugenol but also lignin-oil and even real lignin. Dong et al. reported a Nb-based catalyst process with high yield of propyl phenol proceed in water [21]. The water solvent can completely avoid the transmethylation by-product, therefore increases the selectivity to phenolics. The key step in obtaining alkyl phenols from lignin monomers is the selective cleavage of the CO bonds while remaining the Ar-OH bonds and aromatic rings, which requires the rational design of a catalyst for HDO [24–26]. When the HDO capacity of the catalyst is overwhelming to hydrolysis or hydrogenation, the CO bonds could be completely removed. However, the Ar-OH bonds would be removed in most cases, and the benzene ring will be hydrogenated, which is unconducive to the preparation of alkyl phenols. Sakthivel reported complete hydrogenation of eugenol with ruthenium-containing nickel hydrotalcite (NiRu-HT)-type materials. Eugenol was hydrogenated to dihydroeugenol, then demethoxy and aromatic ring hydrogenation were carried out simultaneously to form propyl-cyclohexanol [27]. The synergy between catalytic site with different roles is the key for catalyst design for comprehensive task [28]. Molybdenum carbide (MoC) has been identified as a highly efficient catalyst due to its unique d-band electron properties similar to noble metals [29,30]. It represents tremendous potential in many catalytic reactions such as hydrogen production, [31,32] water gas shift reaction [33] and biomass conversion [34–37]. The intercalation of carbon into the lattice of Mo offers a considerable improvement in stability [38]. The formation of Mo-C bonds modifies the electronic properties of Mo, such as decreasing in its density of states near the Fermi level and charge transfer from metal to carbon, which displays a unique combination of the physical properties characteristic of noble metals and ceramics [39]. In this study, we report on the selective HDO from dihydroeugenol (DHE, one of the major monomers derived from lignin, G-Type phenols) to alkyl phenols over Pd/α-MoC catalyst under mild condition, as shown in Scheme 1 . The Pd/α-MoC demonstrated high conversion of dihydroeugenol and selectivity to alkyl phenols. The results of catalyst characterizations suggest that the Pd/α-MoC catalyst exhibits high levels of oxygen vacancies and acidity sites, which promotes the conversion of lignin monomer and selectivity to alkyl phenols. The consecutive tests with reuse of the catalysts were carried out to measure the stability of Pd/α-MoC, which shows a good performance of selective HDO as fresh catalyst. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Dihydroeugenol (>98%), n-dodecane (>99%), anisole (>99%), phenol (>99%), dimethoxyphenol (>99), guaiacol (98%), 3-methoxyphenol (97%), 4-methoxyphenol (99%), catechol (99%), Veratrole (≥99%), n-hexadecane (98%) and methylcyclohexane (>99%) were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Bio-Chem Technology Co., Ltd. Pd(NO3)2 and Al2O3 were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. TiO2 and (NH4)6Mo7O24 were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. Toluene (>99.5%) was purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. SiO2 (Q10) was purchased from Nankai Catalyst Co., Ltd. All chemicals were used without further purification. 2.2 Catalysts preparation The α-MoC based catalysts are prepared according to the literature with modification [32,40]. Typically, 2 g (NH4)6Mo7O24 was dissolved in 10 mL of deionized water and stirred for 20 min at room temperature. Next, the required amount of Pd(NO3)2 was dissolved in 5 mL of deionized water with ultrasonic treatment, and then injected slowly into the (NH4)6Mo7O24 aqueous solution. The mixture solution was stirred for 4 h at room temperature and then heated to 80 °C until all the water was evaporated. The solid obtained was dried in a vacuum overnight and calcined in air at 500 °C for 4 h with a heating rate of 5 °C /min. Finally, the sample was carbonized in tube furnace using a temperature-programmed carbonization protocol. The initial temperature was 30 °C and was raised at a rate of 5 °C /min to 700 °C, where it was held for 120 min. The gas ratio of H2/CH4 was 4:1 and total gas flow was 60 mL/min. Pd/MoO3 was synthesized in same way without the temperature-programmed carbonization. The nominal content of Pd was 0.2 at% in α-MoC catalysts. The α-MoC was synthesized in the way according to the literature [32]. Meanwhile, TiO2, Al2O3 and SiO2 supported Pd catalysts were prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation method. 1 g of oxide substrate was dispersed in 10 mL of deionized and stirred for 20 min at room temperature. Pd(NO3)2 and (NH4)6Mo7O24 were dissolved in 5 mL of deionized water with ultrasonic treatment respectively and injected slowly into the substrate aqueous dispersion. The mixture solution was stirred for 4 h at room temperature and heated to 80 °C until all the water was completely evaporated. The obtained solid was dried in vacuum overnight and calcined in air at 500 °C for 4 h with a heating rate of 5 °C/min. The nominal content of Pd was 0.2 wt%. The loading of Mo was 0.5 wt%. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images and High-Angle Annular Dark Field Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images were conducted on a FEI Talos F200S G2 microscope at 200 kV (FEI, USA). Powder XRD patterns was conducted by using an X-ray diffractometer (Smart Lab SE, Rigaku, Japan) equipped with Cu Kα radiation. The diffraction patterns are referenced with Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards (JCPDS) data base. ICP-OES was performed on an iCAP 7000 Series (Thermo Scientific, US). Sample was dissolved and ultrasounded in a sulfuric acid and nitric acid mixed solution before analysis. Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms of the samples were obtained on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 Plus sorption analyzer. The pore size distribution was calculated by the Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) was carried out on an apparatus (Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were recorded on a Thermo Scientific ESCA lab 250 Xi spectrometer equipped with monochromatic Al Kα radiation, and the results were calibrated by a C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV. All of the photoemission spectra were fit with symmetric Gaussian-Lorentzian (80/20) line-shapes. 2.4 Hydrodeoxygenation reaction The catalytic reactions were proceeded in a 25 mL stainless steel autoclave with a quartz tube lining. Typically, 0.5 g dihydroeugenol, 9.5 g solvent and 0.1 g catalyst were added to quartz tube lining. The reactor was sealed and purged with H2 five times. The initial pressure of H2 was 0.5 MPa. Then the autoclave was heated to a required temperature under magnetic stirring at 500 rpm and kept for a certain reaction time. After the reaction, the reactor was quenched in an ice water bath immediately. 2.5 Product analysis methods The organic phase of HDO reaction was qualitatively analyzed using a GC–MS (Shimadzu GCMS-QP 2010 SE) equipped with an SH-Rxi-5Sil MS column, and then quantitatively analyzed by a GC-FID (Shimadzu GC-2014) equipped with a Stabilwax-DA column. n-Dodecane was used as an internal standard for the quantification of the liquid products. The typical GC-MS spectrum and GC-FID spectrum of the HDO reactions are shown in Fig. S6. The MS spectra of products resulting from the HDO of DHE are shown in Fig. S7. The organic phase of the substrate scope investigation was qualitatively and quantitatively analyzed using a GC–MS (Shimadzu GCMS-QP 2010 SE) equipped with an SH-Rxi-5Sil MS column. n-Hexadecane was used as an internal standard for the quantification of the liquid products. Conversion and selectivity were determined according to the following equations [41–43]: Conversion = ( 1 − moles of residual substrate moles of initial substrate ) × 100 % Selectivity = ( moles of total alkyl phenols moles of total products ) × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterizations of catalysts The crystal phase of the catalysts was determined by XRD. As shown in Fig. 1 , the XRD patterns of fresh Pd/α-MoC and Pd/α-MoC after catalysis (marked as used in this work) are identical. The diffraction peaks at 37.7, 43.7, 63.4, 75.7 and 79.8° of Pd/α-MoC and Pd/α-MoC-used are assigned to (111), (200), (220), (311), (222) of α-MoC (JCPDS PDF # 00–015–0457), respectively [44,45]. The identical XRD patterns of fresh and used Pd/α-MoC suggested that the bulk crystal structure of Pd/α-MoC was well maintained after HDO reaction. For the Pd/TiO2 catalyst, the diffraction peaks at 25.4, 37.9, 48.2, 54.1, 62.3° are attributed to the anatase TiO2 phase (JCPDS PDF # 00–021–1272) and the peaks at 27.5, 36.1, 39.3, 41.3, 54.4 and 56.8° are attributed to the rutile TiO2 phase (JCPDS PDF # 00–021–1276), respectively. For Pd/MoO3, the diffraction peaks at 23.4, 25.9, 27.4, 33.8, 39.1, 46.4 and 55.2° are assigned to the MoO3 phase (JCPDS PDF # 00–047–1320). The diffraction patterns of Pd/γ-Al2O3 and Pd/SiO2 do not show any sharp peaks, suggesting the amorphous characteristics or poor crystallinity of supports. The XRD patterns of all the samples show no obvious diffraction peaks of Pd because of the very low loading of Pd. The surface properties and elemental analysis results of the Pd/α-MoC catalysts are summarized in Table 1 . The fresh and used Pd/α-MoC catalysts exhibit similar average BET surface area of 76–86 m2g−1 with the pore size centered around 5.2–7.2 nm and pore volume was about 0.136–0.166 cm3g−1. This result indicates that Pd/α-MoC catalyst maintained a porous structure after the reaction. For the comparison catalysts, the Pd/SiO2 exhibits the highest surface area (262 m2g−1) and pore volume (1.066 cm3g−1) and the Pd/Al2O3 shows a lower surface area and pore volume (143 m2g−1, 0.650 cm3g−1) than Pd/SiO2 but higher than Pd/α-MoC. For Pd/TiO2, the surface area is 51 m2g−1 and pore volume is 0.322 cm3g−1. The Pd/MoO3 exhibits much lower surface area (4 m2g−1) and pore volume (0.019 cm3g−1), suggested a non-porous structure. The N2 sorption isotherms (Fig. S1) of all samples except Pd/MoO3 correspond to the H2(b) type of hysteresis loop, which suggested the pores in supports are formed by stacked structure. The element analysis results confirmed that the actual Pd loading of Pd/α-MoC was consistent to the nominal loading (0.2 atomic%). After the catalyst had undergone two reaction cycles, the Pd content remained the same as that of the fresh catalyst according to the ICP-OES experiments. The acidic property of the catalysts was revealed by NH3-TPD experiments as shown in Fig. 2 . The NH3-TPD results show that the Pd/α-MoC catalyst contains a certain amount of acidity sites, however, which was basically unchanged before and after the reaction. The acidic sites are assigned to the hydroxyl groups on the surface of α-MoC [46]. The quantity of desorbed NH3 was calibrated and quantitatively calculated and the results were shown in Table S3. The quantity of desorbed NH3 was 0.22 mmol/g for the test of fresh and used Pd/α-MoC, which is similar to the value of the Pd/Al2O3 (0.21 mmol/g). Nevertheless, there are almost no acidic sites in Pd/MoO3 and Pd/SiO2, which suggested the lack of the hydroxyl groups on the surface. Because of the reduction of O species in TiO2 by NH3, [47] the area of NH3-TPD curve in the test of Pd/TiO2 within 100–350 °C includes a certain amount of H2O and NOx, which makes the quantity of desorbed NH3 was hardly to calculated. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was employed to obtain the morphology and element distribution of the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 3 b, the lattice fringes of 0.21 nm are observed, which is consistent with the lattice of α-MoC (200). The HAADF-STEM image and corresponding energy dispersive spectra of fresh and used catalysts (Fig. 3c,d and Fig. S3) further confirmed that the Pd atom was distributed with a high dispersion. No clusters or particles of Pd atoms are observed [37,40]. 3.2 Hydrodeoxygenation of DHE over various Pd-based catalysts The results of the HDO of DHE over different Pd-based catalysts were analyzed and compared, as shown in Fig. 4 . The conditions for the HDO reactions were kept constant, and the maximum conversion of DHE over all catalysts was maintained below 80% to illustrate the activity difference. It is found that the Pd/α-MoC showed an excellent catalytic performance compared with Pd/Al2O3, Pd/TiO2, Pd/SiO2 and Pd/MoO3. The conversion and selectivity to propyl-phenol (1) of Pd/α-MoC are significantly higher than other catalysts. The by-products of HDO over Pd/α-MoC include propyl-anisole (2) and methyl-dihydroeugenol (3). The methyl group in methyl-dihydroeugenol was caused by transmethylation [48]. Due to the presence of acidity sites on the surface of Pd/α-MoC, the methanol removed from DHE molecules and the methyl in organic solvents were added to substrates and products, which resulted in the selectivity to methyl-dihydroeugenol and other transmethylation products. No propyl-cyclohexanol (4) was detected, indicating the further hydrogenation of propylphenol was prevented over Pd/α-MoC. Over the Pd/Al2O3, the conversion of DHE is 44.8% and the products are mainly methyl-dihydroeugenol and propyl-catechol (2). The selectivity to propyl-phenol is only 5.1%, which shows an incomplete HDO activity of DHE. In term of the result of HDO over Pd/TiO2, the conversion is lower than 17.7% and the selectivity to propyl-phenol is 50.5%. The by-products mainly include propyl-anisole, methyl-dihydroeugenol and propyl-cyclohexanone (5). The presence of propyl-cyclohexanone suggests that the further hydrogenation of propyl-phenol was conducted over Pd/TiO2. The other products in the HDO tests over Pd/Al2O3 and Pd/TiO2 are some transmethylation products unquantified. Over the Pd/SiO2 and Pd/MoO3 catalysts, the conversions are much lower than 10% and the selectivity is not very accurate because of the low content of products in catalytic system. The main product is propyl-phenol and the by-products are transmethylation products and over-hydrogenation products. Moreover, as the results shown in Table S6, even if the reaction time or catalyst usage is increased by 3-4 times, the conversion and selectivity over Pd/Al2O3, Pd/TiO2, Pd/MoO3 are still far lower than those of Pd/α-MoC. According to previous reports, [49–51] the acidic property of the catalysts could enhance the conversion of biomass compounds. As the results of NH3-TPD and HDO tests, the trend of conversion of substrates is that Pd/α-MoC > Pd/Al2O3 > Pd/TiO2 > Pd/MoO3 > Pd/SiO2, which is proportional to the content of acidity sites. It suggests that the acidity-rich property of Pd/α-MoC contributes to a high HDO activity. 3.3 Hydrodeoxygenation of DHE over Pd/α-MoC To further confirm the HDO activity of the Pd/α-MoC catalyst, the catalytic performance of Pd/α-MoC as the function of reaction temperature, H2 initial pressure and reaction time were evaluated by selective HDO of dihydroeugenol to alkyl phenols as shown in Fig. 5 and Table S2. As the reaction temperature increased, a rapid increase in substrate conversion was observed along with a corresponding increase in selectivity, reaching a maximum of 96% at around 280 °C (Fig. 5a). The conversion also increased rapidly with increasing H2 initial pressure, reaching 92.3% selectivity at 0.5 MPa (Fig. 5b). The HDO of lignin monomers usually requires a high pressure of hydrogen owing to the high bond energy of CO bond [19–23]. Surprisingly, the HDO could readily occur under ambient H2 pressure which is much lower than the literature reported (compared in Table S1). For example, under atmospheric pressure of hydrogen (1 bar), the selectivity is still higher than 89% and the conversion is almost 50%. In the following investigation, the H2 pressure of 0.5 MPa is adopted as the optimal pressure for following studies. In Fig. 5(c), by conducting HDO experiments on the substrate at 280 °C, the relationship between conversion and time is obtained. It can be deduced that as the reaction time increases, the conversion gradually increases, while the selectivity remains basically unchanged (higher than 96% at 2 h). The reaction could finish in about 2 h. The carbon balance of HDO reactions were shown in Table S2. Thus, the Pd/α-MoC shows a remarkable capability to selective activate CO bonds efficiently and preserves the Ar-OH groups and aromatic rings from being hydrogenated, which leads to a high selectivity to alkyl phenols. 3.4 The critical role of Pd chemical states and α-MoC in the hydrodeoxygenation To further explore the role of Pd and α-MoC in the hydrodeoxygenation, the chemical states of O, Pd and Mo in different catalyst were investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) in Fig. 6 . The O 1 s spectrum is deconvoluted to 3 components (Fig. 6a) and the fitting results are tabulated in Table 2 , corresponding to lattice oxygen (O1), chemisorbed oxygen (captured by the oxygen vacancies, O2) and hydroxyl oxygen (O3), respectively [21,52,53]. Comparing all these catalysts, fresh and used Pd/α-MoC, Pd/Mo/Al2O3, Pd/Al2O3 and Pd/TiO2 exhibit three distinct oxygen species, but Pd/MoO3 and Pd/SiO2 has only two distinct oxygen species. The ratio of three oxygen species in different catalysts are shown in Table 2. The oxygen species of Pd/α-MoC were existed due to the oxidation of molybdenum and palladium on the surface of catalysts. The ratio of O2 species in Pd/α-MoC are much higher than others, indicating more oxygen vacancies existed. The ratio of O2 species in Pd/Al2O3 is 18%, which is lower than that of Pd/α-MoC but still higher than others. There is almost no O3 species in Pd/TiO2 and Pd/MoO3, and the ratio of O2 species is also quiet low. In the spectrum of Pd/SiO2, the O2 species is not detected and O1 species reaches 96%. Notably, after the addition of Mo, the ratio of O2 species in Pd/Mo/Al2O3 decreased from 18% to 13%. This phenomenon indicate that oxidized molybdenum could be deactivated sites to oxygen vacancy. According to previous reports, [54–56] oxygen vacancy could provide the reducing power to facilitate the strong energetic penalty of breaking the CO bond, which leads to a high activity in promoting the hydrodeoxygenation reaction. As the results of HDO tests, Pd/α-MoC shows a remarkable HDO activity and the trend of conversion is that Pd/α-MoC > Pd/Al2O3 > Pd/TiO2 > Pd/TiO2 > Pd/MoO3 > Pd/SiO2. It is totally corresponded to the trend of content of oxygen vacancies. This illustrates that the Pd/α-MoC catalyst has strong ability to bond and break the CO in lignin monomers. The Pd 3d spectra of all samples were hardly to be observed due to low loading concentration as shown in Fig 6b. The Pd 3d spectrum of fresh catalyst is deconvoluted to two doublets. The Pd 3d5/2 peaks around 336.0 and 336.8 eV were attributed to the charged and uncharged Pd in PdO, respectively. The binding energy of 336.0 eV is slightly lower than oxidized Pd, which is due to the electron transfer from support to Pd [57]. The Pd 3d spectrum of used Pd/α-MoC (Fig. S2) were hardly to observe. The poor signal could be attributed to the encapsulation of Pd atoms by α-MoC during reaction. The Pd 3d5/2 peaks at 337.5 and 338.4 eV in the spectrum of Pd/MoO3 were attributed to the Pd in PdO and PdO2.The fitting results of Pd 3d spectra are tabulated in Table 3 . The trend of content of Pdα (charged Pd) is corresponding to that of O2 species, which suggests that the oxygen species of Pd/α-MoC contributes to more charged Pd atom and stronger ability to facilitate the H2 activation. The Mo 3d spectrum in the Pd/α-MoC catalysts shows five pairs of peaks. Peaks observed at 228.4 eV, were attributed to Mo present in the α-MoC structure [58–61]. Peaks at 229.8 eV were attributed to Mo4+, likely in the form of MoO2 [58,62–64]. Doublets with Mo 3d5/2 peaks at 232.8 eV were assigned to MoO3, corresponding to Mo in the 6+ oxidation state [58,62,63,65]. Additionally, peaks were observed at 231.0 and 228.8 eV and were attributed to Mo in 3+ and 5+ oxidation states, respectively, and may correspond to Mo present in the form of an oxycarbide phase [58,62]. The spectra in the Pd/Mo/Al2O3 and Pd/MoO3 catalysts show two pairs of peaks, assigned to Mo in the 5+ and 6+ oxidation state. As the analysis of XPS data, the Pd/α-MoC exhibits more oxygen vacancies and charged Pd atoms than the comparison catalysts, which resulted in the stronger capability to activate hydrogen and break the CO bond in lignin monomers. 3.5 Substrates scope and reaction pathway Selective HDO evaluation over different substrate molecules were performed to explore the reaction pathway as summarized in Table 4 . The stability of Ar-OH group in products was examined firstly as shown in entry 1–4. Guaiacol was investigated as the substrate. The molecule structure of guaiacol is similar to DHE except missing a propyl group. The conversion of guaiacol increased rapidly as the increasing of reaction time, while the selectivity to phenol was 70%. The reaction finished in ∼2 h. As the reaction time continued to increase, the selectivity to phenol remained stable at 70%, while the selectivity of hydrogenation products remained unchanged, suggesting that the further HDO or hydrogenation of phenol products on Pd/α-MoC catalyst is not a preferred route. The influence of the presence of phenolic hydroxyl group (Ar-OH) was investigated via the selective HDO reactions over substrates containing different number of Ar-OH groups. As the content of Ar-OH group increased, the conversion of substrate increased rapidly. As shown in entry 13 and 14, the conversion of catechol was 100% and the selectivity to phenol was 60–70%. When phenol was used as the substrate (entry 9 and 10), the conversion was much lower than that of catechol and the products of the reaction were hydrogenation product. Moreover, the anisole was examined as the reaction substrate (entry 7 and 8), the conversion was as low as 22.3%, while the major product was hydrogenation product which was similar to that of phenol. The HDO rate exhibits the trend that catechol > phenol > anisole. Obviously, the presence of Ar-OH group remarkably improved the conversion of selective HDO over Pd/α-MoC catalyst. We proposed that the substrate was bonded with the oxygen vacancies on the surface of the Pd/α-MoC catalysts by Ar-OH group. The more content of Ar-OH groups in substrates brought a higher possibility of bonding. Besides, the oxygen vacancies on the surface of the Pd/α-MoC catalysts could charge the substrate by transferring electrons. This could activate the substrate and makes it easier to be hydrogenated with the hydrogen dissociated by Pd atoms. Thus, it is suggested that the selective HDO of DHE was conducted on the surface of α-MoC after the Ar-OH group bonded with Pd/α-MoC. The selective HDO tests over meta-substrate and para-substrate were conducted to explore the influence of the relative positions of the methoxy group and the Ar-OH group. The results were shown as entry 15–18. The conversions of meta-substrate and para-substrate were much lower than that of ortho-substrate (guaiacol, entry 5 and 6). Besides, the selectivity to phenol was decreased significantly, comparing with the results of entry 5 and 6. Notably, the selectivity to anisole was soared, which is almost ten times that of entry 5. The HDO rate exhibits the trend that ortho-substrate > meta-substrate > para-substrate. As we proposed, it is a preferred process that the Ar-OH group of substrates bonded with the Pd/α-MoC before the selective HDO was conducted. The Ar-OH group was bonded on the surface of Pd/α-MoC and the CO group in meta-substrate and para-substrate was in a position that unconducive to bond with the catalyst. The removal of the CO group is much slower than that of ortho-substrate. As the reaction proceeds, the Ar-OH is removed to form anisole with higher selectivity. In the selective HDO reaction, the removal of the CO group of dihydroeugenol is a fast step, while the removal of the Ar-OH is a slow step. We propose that the adsorption and desorption with the Pd/α-MoC catalyst of the substrates depends on the oxygen vacancies and the electron density of the aromatic ring. During the adsorption process of the substrate by the catalyst, due to the existence of the methoxy group, the electron-donating functional group leads to an increase in the electron density of the aromatic ring. Meanwhile, the electron density of Ar-OH group would increase because of its inductive electron-withdrawing effect, which was in favor of the combination of the Ar-OH group and the oxygen vacancies of Pd/α-MoC. The methoxy group was removed in the formation of methanol after the selective HDO was conducted and the electron density of the aromatic ring decreased, resulting in a decrease of the electron density of the Ar-OH group. The binding capacity of the Ar-OH and the oxygen vacancies was weakened, resulting in the desorption of the generated alkyl phenols on the surface of Pd/α-MoC. Thus, the massive Ar-OH groups in the lignin monomers could be used as the bonding sites of the Pd/α-MoC catalyst in the scenario of lignin upgrading, which can be stably adsorbed with the Pd/α-MoC catalyst to remove other groups on the aromatic rings. Meanwhile, the Pd/α-MoC catalyst will not cleave the phenolic hydroxyl group, which effectively improves the selectivity of alkyl phenols. The results of the selective HDO of guaiacol on Pd/α-MoC catalyst with different contents of Pd are shown in Table 5 . The state of the Pd atoms in the Pd/α-MoC catalyst determines the reaction pathway. When the Pd content is 0.2 at% in catalyst (entry 3 and 4), as we prepared, the conversion is over 67% and 95% at the reaction time of 1 and 2 h. The selectivity to phenol was maintained at about 70%. Moreover, even if the amount of catalyst added is increased to three times, with the extension of the reaction time, the selectivity of phenol is remained stable at about 70%. As the α-MoC catalyst was used which not containing Pd (entry 1 and 2), the conversion is much lower than that of entry 3 and 4, while the main product is phenol. The decrease of conversion is due to the poor capability of dissociating hydrogen over α-MoC without Pd atoms. However, when the Pd content in the catalyst is over 1 and 5 at% (entry 8–11), the main product of the reactions is HYD product, which means a hydrogenation of Ar-OH were conducted, causing the cleavage of Ar-OH and CO groups to form HYD products. This fact shows that the highly dispersed Pd atoms would not cleave the Ar-OH groups while removing the CO groups in lignin monomers. The conversion over catalysts containing Pd of 1 and 5 at% decreased slightly because of the reduction of BET surface area, which was studied in our previous work. [40] The surface area of catalysts containing Pd of 1 and 5 at% are 67 and 51 m2/g, which is lower than that of catalyst containing Pd of 0.2 at%, causing a decrease of conversion. The high content of Pd resulted in an existence of Pd particles or clusters, [40] which would cause the removal of Ar- OH group. The synergistic effect of highly dispersed Pd and α-MoC support is the reason for the high selectivity of phenolic products. Proposed reaction pathway for the selective HDO reactions of dihydroeugenol in the presence of Pd/α-MoC is depicted in Scheme 2. Firstly, the dihydroeugenol was adsorbed on α-MoC via Ar–OH group. Subsequently, hydrogen dissociated from the Pd atom was added to the CO group, leading to the formation of methanol and alkyl phenols. Methanol and dimethyl ester in liquid phase were detected by GC/MS. Methane in gas phase was detected by GC-TCD. Dimethyl ester is formed by the reaction of two molecules of methanol under the catalysis of acidic sites on the Pd/α-MoC. 3.6 Reusability of the Pd/α-MoC catalyst The reusability test on Pd/α-MoC was conducted in Fig. 7 . After each reaction, the catalyst was collected and regenerated by temperature-programmed carbonization. The result showed that after four cycles, the catalyst still remained a remarkable activity. 4 Conclusions In summary, we report the catalytic transformation of lignin monomers to alkyl phenols under mild condition with high conversion and high selectivity. The HDO activity tests and catalyst characterizations suggest that the Pd/α-MoC catalyst has excellent performance for the selective HDO of dihydroeugenol to obtain alkyl phenols such as propylphenol. The oxygen vacancies on the surface of Pd/α-MoC acts as the strong adsorption sites for the Ar-OH group and contribute to keep the charged state of Pd atoms. The presence of highly dispersed Pd atoms promotes the dissociation of hydrogen and prevents the over-hydrogenation of products. The synergistic effect between the Pd and α-MoC promotes the departure of the CO group while maintaining the Ar-OH group, which further leading to the HDO activity under mild condition. Meanwhile, the catalyst also maintained good stability after the reaction. The Pd/α-MoC catalyst shows a possibility of converting lignin monomers under mild condition with low hydrogen pressure. This work not only reports a new route to harvest phenols from biomass, but also develops the catalyst design for comprehensive catalytic process such as HDO. coredata.dc:description: Alkyl phenol is an essential chemical intermediate that is in high demand in the chemical industry. The synthesis of alkyl phenols from lignin-derived molecules is one of the most promising routes for utilizing biomass resources. Herein, we report the catalytic hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of dihydroeugenol (DHE) to alkyl phenols over a highly dispersed Pd/α-MoC catalyst with a substrate conversion of 98% and a selectivity of 96% to alkyl phenols. The Pd/α-MoC catalyst prepared by co-precipitation and temperature-programmed carbonization exhibits exceptional HDO activity under mild conditions with a low H2 pressure (1–10 bars). The characterizations of the catalyst suggest that Pd are highly dispersed on the α-MoC matrix. The reaction mechanism was investigated using the substrate scope experiments. Under ambient pressure, the abundant oxygen vacancies and acidity sites on Pd/α-MoC enable the selective hydrodeoxygenation of lignin monomers.
coredata.dc:title: Harvesting alkyl phenols from lignin monomers via selective hydrodeoxygenation under ambient pressure on Pd/α-MoC catalysts
